text: 1. Speech is his (the breath's) rope, the names the knots 2 . Thus by his speech as by a rope, and by his names as by knots, all this is bound. For all this are names indeed, and with speech he calls everything.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 2. People carry him who knows this, as if they were bound by a rope.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 3. Of the body of the breath thus meditated on, the Ush n ih verse forms the hairs, the Gâyatrî the skin, the Trish t ubh the flesh, the Anush t ubh the muscles, the G agatî the bone, the Paṅkti the marrow, the B ri hatî the breath 3 (prâ n a). He is covered with the verses (kha n d as, metres). Because he is thus covered with verses, therefore they call them kha n d as (coverings, metres).

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 4. If a man knows the reason why kha n d as are called kha n d as, the verses cover him in whatever place he likes against any evil deed.

text: 5. This is said by a Ri shi (Rv. I, 164, 13):--

text: 6. 'I saw (the breath) as a guardian, never tiring, coming and going on his ways (the arteries). That breath (in the body, being identified with the sun among the Devas), illuminating the principal and intermediate quarters of the sky, is returning constantly in the midst of the worlds.'

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: He says: 'I saw a guardian,' because he, the breath, is a guardian, for he guards everything.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 7. He says: 'Never tiring,' because the breath never rests.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 8. He says: 'Coming and going on his ways,' because the breath comes and goes on his ways.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 9. He says: 'Illuminating the principal and intermediate,' because he illuminates these only, the principal and intermediate quarters of the sky.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Aitareya-Âranyaka: ... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 10. He says. 'He is returning constantly in the midst of the worlds,' because he returns indeed constantly in the midst of the worlds.

text: 11. And then, there is another verse (Rv. I, 55, 81): 'They are covered like caves by those who make them,'

text: 12. For all this is covered indeed by breath.
